response_parsed.title: Deep Dive: _zoneinfo Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer delves into the _zoneinfo standard library module, a significant addition to Python 3.12+ that provides built-in support for time zones and daylight saving time.
key_points: _zoneinfo is part of the standard library in Python 3.12+
It offers built-in support for handling time zones and daylight saving time
Allows for consistent handling of dates across different time zones
Improves compatibility with other programming languages and platforms

code_examples.code:
from _datetime import datetime, timezone

# Create a time object in Pacific Time Zone
pt = datetime(2023, 5, 15, tzinfo=timezone.utc - timedelta(hours=7))
print(pt)

from pytz import timezone
# Create a time object in New York Time Zone (Eastern Standard Time)
ny = timezone('America/New_York')
dt = datetime(2023, 5, 15, tzinfo=ny)
print(dt)

version_notes: Improves upon the older pytz library's timezone handling
caveats: Not all operating systems may include _zoneinfo by default
Ensure your system has the latest version of Python (3.12+) for full functionality
Be aware that using _zoneinfo will break compatibility with older Python versions
